ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Re: jmxclient operation arguments...
ygData.msgSnippet: Its hard to help when I can t reproduce.  Is the cmdline-jmxclient that you are using from the Heritrix 1.10.1 $HERITRIX_HOME/bin?  I do not see a 1.5.1 JDK

Its hard to help when I can't reproduce.  Is the cmdline-jmxclient that 
you are using from the Heritrix 1.10.1 $HERITRIX_HOME/bin?  I do not see 
a 1.5.1 JDK (Latest 1.5 seems to be an update 10 to 1.5.0).  I tried w/ 
1.6.0 and that works for me.  Are you on windows?  One random thought: 
remove the '-' from your bean name.   See if that works.

St.Ack


javarahl wrote:
>
> (Hmm - my replies seem to be vanishing...)
>
> That extraneous 'org.archive.jmx.Client' was a cut/paste error from
> an experiment I ran where I exploded the jar.
>
> The command I'm running is:
>
> java -jar cmdline-jmxclient.jar admin:password localhost:8871 global-
> scope:name=TestBean testArgs=foo
>
> I still get the ParseException.
>
> I looked at the source to see the pattern:
>
> protected static final Pattern CMD_LINE_ARGS_PATTERN =
> Pattern.compile("^([^=]+)(?:(?://=)(.+))?$");
>
> I created a little driver program to test that pattern, and it
> reject anything of the form xxxx=yyyy. I'm very puzzled how it can
> work...? I'm using JDK 1.5.1 - is it a JDK issue?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Mike
>
> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com 
> <mailto:archive-crawler%40yahoogroups.com>, Michael Stack <stack@...>
> wrote:
> >
> > The format is argValues separated by commas (Not argType then
> > argValue). You seem to have an
> extraneous 'org.archive.jmx.Client' in
> > your TestBean sample below. Try leaving this out. Below is
> transcript
> > of a session getting and setting logging levels that might be of
> help:
> >
> > stack@bregeon:~/tmp/heritrix-1.10.1$ java -jar
> > bin/cmdline-jmxclient-0.10.5.jar controlRole:letmein
> localhost:8849
> > java.util.logging:type=Logging
> getLoggerLevel=org.archive.crawler.Heritrix
> > 01/03/2007 12:10:32 -0800 org.archive.jmx.Client
> > getLoggerLevel=org.archive.crawler.Heritrix: INFO
> > stack@bregeon:~/tmp/heritrix-1.10.1$ java -jar
> > bin/cmdline-jmxclient-0.10.5.jar controlRole:letmein
> localhost:8849
> > java.util.logging:type=Logging
> > setLoggerLevel=org.archive.crawler.Heritrix,FINE
> > stack@bregeon:~/tmp/heritrix-1.10.1$ java -jar
> > bin/cmdline-jmxclient-0.10.5.jar controlRole:letmein
> localhost:8849
> > java.util.logging:type=Logging
> getLoggerLevel=org.archive.crawler.Heritrix
> > 01/03/2007 12:10:49 -0800 org.archive.jmx.Client
> > getLoggerLevel=org.archive.crawler.Heritrix: FINE
> >
> > St.Ack
> >
> >
> > javarahl wrote:
> > >
> > > When using the excellent jmxclient utilitly, I'm having trouble
> > > supplying arguments to operations. I *am* able to use no-arg
> > > operations successfully.
> > >
> > > I'm attempting to follow the example in the Client source:
> > >
> > > " To set set logging level to FINE on a password protected
> > > JVM:\n" +
> > > " % java -jar cmdline-jmxclient-X.X.jar
> > > controlRole:secret" +
> > > " localhost:8081 //\n" +
> > > " java.util.logging:type=Logging //\n" +
> > > " setLoggerLevel=org.archive.crawler.Heritrix,FINE";
> > >
> > > But every time I try to specify an arg, I'm getting
> > >
> > > Exception in thread "main" java.text.ParseException: Failed
> parse of
> > > setLoggerLevel=org.archive.crawler.Heritrix,FINE
> > > at org.archive.jmx.Client$CommandParse.parse(client.java:573)
> > >
> > > Is the format supposed to be: operation=argType,argValue ? The
> docs
> > > aren't quite clear to me...
> > >
> > > I tried aiming jmxclient at one of my own apps, and I'm able to
> call
> > > no-arg operations perfectly:
> > >
> > > java -jar cmdline-jmxclient.jar org.archive.jmx.Client
> > > admin:password localhost:8871 global-scope:name=TestBean
> testNoArgs
> > > 01/03/2007 14:25:57 -0500 org.archive.jmx.Client testNoArgs: I
> work!
> > >
> > > But if I call an operation that takes a single string, I cannot
> get
> > > it to work. The operation signature is:
> > >
> > > public String testArgs(String argName);
> > >
> > > testArgs=somestring
> > > testArgs=java.lang.String,somestring
> > > testArgs=argName:somestring
> > >
> > > With each, I get the same ParseException I listed above.
> > >
> > > Any help is greatly appreciated.
> > >
> > > (And as I said, great app!)
> > >
> > > Thanks,
> > >
> > > Mike Brown
> > >
> > >
> >
>
>
